commentBody: Did anyone else have "Faceplants" instead of "Fakeplants" for 5 minutes after solving before realizing your error? Just me??

I found all the medium long entries in this puzzle delightful: HERDINGCATS, FAKEPLANTS, GETSABADRAP, SINKORSWIM and any reference to ANIMALFARM (George Orwell‚Äôs farewell to communism) is welcome.  

I was helped by knowing about SEALS in Scottish lore, which I learned from the folk song The Silkie of Sule Skerry, and which reminded me of the lovely trip to Scotland my wife and stepdaughter took in September, in part to visit my daughter, son-in-law and grandson.

My one disagreement with the puzzle is that it doesn‚Äôt seem to me that it takes a long time to get OLD.  It seems to happen in the blink of an eye.

"Is that your final offer for these plants?"
"Yep. Rake it or leaf it!"

(He got a root awakening.)
Absolutely terrific Friday puzzle. I was tripped up by JaNK for a bit and had to grind my way through the NE corner, but it was a good challenge and a good bit of fun. Loved the wordplay in this one.
Link to wordplay breaks since URL uses 2025 instead of 2026 ;)

This felt hard (in a good way!) but came out to just under my Friday average.  I loved HERDINGCATS and thought PERMS was clued quite cleverly.

55A slowed me down a bit because I was certain it was EoiN, ruled it out with APOLLO_II, and then thought "EioN?"

I also had perEnnialS for FAKEPLANTS for a second before remembering they very notably are *not* green all year round.  Quite the opposite, in fact.  Those of you who garden are free to laugh at this.

Very random final note: my grandma and Arthur ASHE were friends :)

One more day to vote on THE GRIDDIES, awards for the best NYT puzzles of 2025. Ballot found here: https://form.jotform.com/253465756808167 Easy to use, nominate as many as five in each of the categories, hit submit and Bob's your uncle! I'll try to put a few samples of the nominations in the replies, in case you want a preview of the ballot, and how Eric Hougland, Marshall Walthew and I would write them up. Please vote, all are welcome, and show your love for your favorite games and the hardworking constructors who made them!

I found this a very challenging but enjoyable puzzle, largely because of Friday-worthy misdirection and opacity, as it should be. Idiomatic expressions and trivia almost stumped me but I persevered and filled the grid without lookups.

Well, almost.

When I typed in the final letter, I got the dreaded "So close" pop-up. FAcEPLANTS are a thing but they are definitely not green all year round ü§£. The composer was an ERIK, not an ERIc, as I had originally assumed, and resolved with Google on my first guess as to which square I needed to check.

FAKE PLANTS became popular in Poland in the 1990s. Otyer than elememts of plastic funeral wreaths they were not available before 1989 and maybe that fact alone enticed Poles to buy them when they arrived - like much other stuff - with market economy. The first IKEA opened in Warsaw in 1991, iirc, and it stocked extremely realistic fake plants, among other things. My mom was fascinated by them and remained so until her death more than 30 years later. I never understood the appeal though. Fake plants, fake smiles, fake-whatever... The genuine article is usually so much better.

PS The broken links really are tiresome, aren't they? How hard can it be to do this right...
Never will quite understand why Van Gogh‚Äôs painting of crows above a wheat field gave me 20A. https://www.vangoghmuseum.nl/en/collection/s0149v1962
Sam Corbin, I like today's picture for "doing some cleaning." Just what could a tiger be licking off its claws??? Yeah, I read too much crime fiction.
This page's URL should be https://www.nytimes.com/2026/01/15/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2026-01-16.html (not ...puzzle-2025-01...)

Cute, fun, fair, and fast.  This one felt right for a Friday to me.  Challenging even if a bit too quickly solved.  The wide expenses were only intimidating for a minute.

Nothing to complain about.  I got held up with the dreaded roman numeral mix for a little bit.

Thanks for this.  When the closest thing to filler crosswordese is AAVE then you've done a nice job.

Loved this one. Beautiful grid design with quadruple triple 9 stacks all with clean and interesting entries. Nice level of difficulty, I had to solve from the bottom up. Really clever clues like ‚ÄúComing out parties?‚Äù BABY SHOWERS, ‚ÄúSecret offering?‚Äù DEODORANT and ‚ÄúMakes do for a while?‚Äù PERMS. I had a lot of incorrect entries to start, FAKE before FAUX, EWAN before EVAN, LADYJANE before JANEGREY, LETSROLL before LETS ROCK, OAK before FIR, and RAT SNAKES and POT SNAKES before PET SNAKES. And of course if you FACE PLANT into the grass it will be green, right? It‚Äôs a wonder I unraveled it all. Also loved the clue for FLOTUS and the fresh clue for YOKO. Lastly, never heard of FOREX‚Äîsounds like code for alimony. Actually, it sounds like a brand name for something I am embarrassed to say and which the emus would probably not allow anyway.

Quite a few answers I did not really know, but these helped me work through those and finish 18% faster than average:
ANIMALFARM
HERDINGCATS
GETSABADRAP
RAUL
ASHE
ANYONEHOME
FAUX

There were a few crossword standbys, but mostly felt fresh.  Thanks, Kyle.

Yeah I don‚Äôt know. Last week took half an hour less, and what‚Äôs the difference?

This puzzle roamed and ransacked across the grid with little to no assistance from an OREO or an ORO. Sure ASHE found a foothold on the Eastern edge but the rest was like getting directions from a dyslexic local who knows how to walk five miles directly through a city without knowing a single street name and arrive where they want to be, when they want to be there.

‚ÄúTake a left at, informally, the street formerly known as Latin 7 but now is called Avenue Faux Pas - go thirty meters and turn left at Katz‚Äôs but stop for the pastrami, then keep going until you hear a tympani drum, you‚Äôre almost there!‚Äù

Anyway I got through without googling anything, at least.

JINK seems excruciatingly geographic - someone in the Northwest might call it a DINK, someone in the Midwest might call it a Poorly Exercised Tactical Response to a Sudden Movement or a spasm, for short.

Blah
zANE GREY was my Ride or Die.  Just couldn‚Äôt let go.
Fun one today, thank you! Loved FAKEPLANTS and AVALANCHE

Lots of white space, no glue, no green paint, only elegant, interesting fill. Now this is what I call a Friday. Nicely done, Kyle. 

The one unknown for me was YOKO Ogawa. Before I came here to post, I read up on her fiction a bit, then immediately JINKed over to my library app and put holds on three of her novels. I‚Äôve had to bump two homegrown writers further down on my reading list for this year to make room for Ogawa (2026 is my Year of the American Novel), but her writing promises to be compelling. Finding a gem like this in a puzzle is such a breath of fresh air after the usual having to parse TV show titles or stage names of pop artists. (Yes, yes, I‚Äôll tell y‚Äôall to get off my lawn before this post is over.)

Other than that, quick but really, really enjoyable, and please don‚Äôt tell anyone I stared and stared at, uh, CART nAILER, having conjured up visions of dray horses and Conestoga wagons (see Year of the American Novel). GETS A BAD nAP is a perfectly valid entry, after all (see Year of the American Novel as it eats into my usually limited anyway sleep), if you fill it in without first reading the clue. 

On that note, it‚Äôs time to get up and grind some beans. Have a good day, everyone.

"Secret offering?" = DEODORANT
"Invitations to come on board" = JOBOFFERS

fiendish clueing and proximate placement led to a devil of a left lower quadrant for me.

Spent a good five minutes wandering around trying to get a foothold on this puzzle...sticking a pluralizing S here and there. Then the clues slowly started to open up. Fun puzzle. Got interrupted by the cat, which didn't help my time, but still around 34 minutes.
For a long time I had Tortoises instead of FAKE PLANTS, so not a lot of success, in the NE, but enjoyed this Friday offering quite alot.
I checked out Lady Jane Grey on Wikipedia. Not such a nice story.

A query, or perhaps a quibble, about 25A. [Shortest-reigning English monarch]. Henry VIII was definitely king and so a reigning wife. But did his wives, whom we would now identify as queens consort, ever have any ruling power?
This was my kind of puzzle. It challenged, but it also gave me some laughs.

@Sam Corbin
Love your columns any day of the week!  No bags of money needed...

I didn't really like this one. A lot of the fill felt like a bit of a stretch for me, didn't particularly like clue/answer combinations for JADING, OLD, LETS ROCK, ATSYMBOL (only ever heard it referred to as an at sign), OHSURE, PERM, among others (I assume it's a perm because it is a temprary hairstyle?). 

I did enjoy learning JINK, AAVE, the fact about SEALS (is that where the term "seely" is from?), CAW, and the twin "Do some cleaning" clues. 

Maybe I'm just bitter because I had to error check ERIK Satie and find out that it wasn't "FAcEPLANTS" stay green all winter. Another I wish I had marinated on a bit before resorting to lookups. Oh well!

Have a good weekend everyone!
Enjoyed that, thank you Kyle. Not too hot, not too cold, just right!

The answer Apollo VII makes no sense. The Apollo (and Mercury) missions have always been referred to using Arabic numerals (i.e. Apollo 7), only the Gemini missions used Roman ones.  I'm surprised the editors didn't catch this (a simple Google would have surfaced the issue) or, if they did, allowed this.

Now I know the constructor would have had to totally redo the lower left quadrant without it, but standards are standards after all.  The editors should have at least qualified the clue by stating the answer was a variant (or something similar to calling it a variant).  As it is, the mismatch between the needed answer and the correct one was an unnecessary obstacle toward completing the puzzle.
NW and SE filled within 10 minutes, 30 minutes to complete the whole puzzle. Thought I was gonna hit a new Friday PB. Still fun to do :)

Quibble and warning: NEVER put gas cans in your trunk. Very bad idea. I can't believe they clued it that way.  
You will be inhaling dangerous fumes when driving. And a lot of cars have a light in their trunk. Granted, modern LEDs are not as dangerous as old filament bulbs, but still a chance of a spark & a car-b-q.

My biggest proof that everything is a simulation and I‚Äôm the main character is when a crossword puzzle clue/word aligns with niche elements of my life. As I travel around the UK right now (about to step off the train to Cambridge!), the wealth of Welsh, Scottish, and English clues today have me quite self-absorbed. But then if I was the main character, I‚Äôm not a very good one. This puzzle stumped me! And in the presence of Cambridge nonetheless. If only I‚Äôd spent a little more time in the British Museum memorizing short-lived monarchs!

A big ‚Äúthank you!‚Äù again for all the warm welcomes yesterday after my crossword comment christening!
This one took me a long time but was a very satisfying Friday.  Well done!

I had a few erasures today. mariA instead of ANITA, scOTUS for FLOTUS (sad but true), seAN for EVAN. The cluing was really nice. [Coming out party?] made me think it was going to be some word for the actual newborn, but the real answer was good as well. Loved SINK OR SWIM, BOOK FAIR, HERDING CATS, ANIMAL FARM and more. Nice clues, low on PPP, some sticky areas, all adding up to a nice Friday puzzle. Inspired by 39 D, Grace Jones with Warm Leatherette: https://youtu.be/Qn4ohXUdo_8?si=1FGk4u-PCQELtxNx
Knew Satie's first name, just couldn't spell it :-s And i think FACEPLANTS are green (lively) all year round too! #CloseButNoCigar
I certainly enjoyed the puzzle but I have some quibbles as a Scot! 21A the name for the creature is a selkie, and 55A the Scottish spelling is Iain!
For 35 Across, Ian is one spelling, in English. Iain is the Gaelic spelling.

Happy to see a puzzle with the appropriate difficulty for a Friday. Would be great if crosswords on Fridays or Saturdays had at least this difficulty going forward - this used to be the case and was much more enjoyable.

Hi Sam, I'm shocked you didn't know HERDING CATS was something done in real life. I'm sure most solvers have seen it. Did you see the link in the first reply in this thread from last night? https://www.nytimes.com/shared/comment/4d7uq4?rsrc=cshare&smid=url-share

Lot of good clues here, most of which I did not get, but sometimes the crossword giveth and sometimes it taketh away. Today it tooketh.

Big fail on the trivia. ANIMALFARM was the only one I knew. Very few short quoted statements (like "Here we go" today), which should have suited me. I tend to find them very hard because the continuum of answers always seems vast. I didn't like CAW for that reason.

Overall really well put together.

I usually do better on Saturday than Friday, so on to tomorrow.

Standouts for me:
‚Ä¢	A new clue for YOKO, as in all Crosslandia's major outlets, it has always referred to Ms. Ono.  A crossworthy clue as well. After reading about Yoko Ogawa, I‚Äôve placed her on my want-to-read list.
‚Ä¢	HERDING CATS!  Hah!  Incorrigibility, thy name is cat.  It‚Äôs one of the reasons that every cat I‚Äôve lived with has stolen my heart.  
‚Ä¢	A sky-high 18 longs, bringing fun and interest to the box.
‚Ä¢	The NE corner, which stayed mostly white for me, even as I came back to it numerous times, and just before I uncle-d, an answer hit me.  Then nada.  Then again, just at breaking point, another answer.  And again and again, a serious grind.  How satisfying that was to fill in.  
‚Ä¢	PuzzPair¬©Ô∏è:  DUST, clued [Do some cleaning], and FAKE PLANTS.  Is this not true?!  Is this not true?!

Standout puzzle, Kyle, a splendid outing.  Thank you!

That's a WRAP!

Nice Friday.
Smooth and creamy in
*just* enough spots to 
help me in the crunchier zones.
(I'm looking at you, JINKS...)

But a fair, frolicking feast 
of facts and fiction.
For Friday.

Fab.

Is this social media? 
( asking for @Friend )



An enjoyable puzzle, where the constructor somehow knew just when to throw my sub-conscious a line.
Very nice puzzle! It ALMOST makes up for yesterday.

Welcome to Fridays, Sam!

I (for one) would be psyched if 
we got to see you *every* Friday
to read your take on your favorite 
solving day.

I'm a Friday fan meself.
Thurtainly a thucker for themeleth!
Nice Friday indeed. Dane Grey was so plausible dinking on ice but alas it wasn‚Äôt to be‚Ä¶

Had the toughest time getting a toe hold on this one but eventually managed to JINK my way to completion.  A couple of comical dead ends (earlGREY, BOt for @symbol) sure did not help.  A nice challenge.   Many thanks.

BABYSHOWER was hilarious.

JADING BOOKFAIR and PERMS are all questionable and quite awkward. 

A fine Friday overall. 

Hope yall have good days

A typical long Friday workout for me, with a lot of things that were only going to come to me with some crosses. But... ended up being a nice challenge with a lot of 'aha' moments when something finally dawned on me. And of course my puzzle find today. A Thursday from August 29, 2019 by Jeff Chen. Really clever one, with a type of theme clues that I don't recall seeing before. Some examples: "Word that can complete CARE___R" GIVEORTAKE "Word that can complete SH___ED" INOROUT "Word that can complete DE_____" FRIENDORFOE "Word that can complete ____ER" BOOMORBUST Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/29/2019&g=61&d=A ...

Nice puzzle. The SW corner destroyed my Friday average, but it was a nice challenge. It took me forever to realize leatherette could be described by two different FA___ words, and that NASA missions could be numbered differently than I was thinking.
In fairness, I think the puzzle should have been solvable both with the first letter or with a rebus.

Nice, difficult Friday puzzle.  Could've been a Saturday (IMHO).

Excellent mixture of tricky clues (I especially enjoyed "Coming-out party?" and "Invitations to come on board") and TIL-opportunities (JINK, YOKO Ogawa and FOREX) and extensions of knowledge (Lady JANE GREY and SEALS/selkies).

If this is Friday, I'm a bit anxious about Saturday, but in a good way.
Thanks for the challenge, Kyle Dolan!

Must have been a very solid puzzle,  since my main "complaint" is that we didn't have "Sean : Ireland :: ___ : Wales" for 55A. 

So we ended up with references to England, Wales and Scotland (twice), but none at all to Ireland. I hope our constructor---with the very Irish-sounding name---takes no offense at this very unfortunate editorial oversight. ;-)

Also HERDINGCATS is an unwieldy *activity*, not an unwieldy "situation".

In any case, this seemed a very nice Friday puzzle. Took me about 35 minutes, but I solved it without help---though my grid was rather barren for quite some time.

TIL about tai chi FANs and JANE GREY's short JINKy life.

Good puzzle, fresh fill to the gills. Thanks, Kyle.
That really tested my chops. Thanks for the wonderful Friday-worthy puzzle!
A model Friday puzzle. Great fun! And hard.

Once again, I'm grateful to Christina Iverson's "Easy Mode" clues.  I needed sixteen of those, plus one Wiki look up (for the actor, who I at first thought was an actress).

Have a good weekend, everyone!
I miss Deb.
This was bad.  Very, very bad. Not sure who Deb is but if she writes good crosswords, I miss her too.

Pleasingly challenging puzzle with some fun cluing!

However I take issue with Sam's comment: "38A. I‚Äôd describe this entry as ‚Äústretchy‚Äù in puzzle parlance because it stretches the limits of a word‚Äôs standard definition to accommodate a looser meaning."

Sam is wrong. And I know a thing or two about words as an esteemed Nobel Laureate in literature*.



*I recently acquired the award at a garage sale. And I'm proud to accept this award that I deserve, maybe more than anyone ever. But being a magananimous person, I feel the writer who first owned the award deserves almost as much credit as I do. Although I've never heard of him or her.
Hardest puzzle in a long time full of things I did not know. Ended up looking up the bit about Scottish folklore to unblock me from the NE.

Nice puzzle, though easy for a Friday, IMHO.  I actually started at the top because "Rita Moreno" caught my eye--and it was Off To The Races.  
Disappointed that LADY JANE GREY was not honored as nobility; she wasn't just Plain JANE.  But I don't want to lose my head over this... (Was CHOPS right below her on purpose?)

We had a TRAILER that we hitched up to our SUV during our move, but I would never refer to it as a CAR TRAILER.  People don't even say TRACTOR-TRAILER anymore.

Got my hopes up for another mention of Kelpie or Selkie or some such there at 21A, but No.  Oh, well.  SEALS are nice.
Also got a little tickled at 56D's "Half-____" as I had several thoughts that were...nonstarters.  I guess I'm easily AMUSEd.

Have a good  lead-in to the weekend, everyone.  Be sure to read Dave Barry's Guide for folks headed to the Monday night game.
They're green year-round. Great Friday chuckle! Grazie, Kyle!

I'm not up on how quickly Henry VIII slaughtered his wives.¬† JANE GREY had a shorter reign than Anne Bolyn?¬† Who knows/remembers?¬† Or did she die of natural causes?

Because of the heroism of a group of brave airline passengers, "here we go" will always be LET'S ROLL to me.¬† But I didn't like the LHE combo with ASHE and AMUSES, and eventually had to change it to LET'S ROCK.¬† Before I changed it, I was sort of screwed up in the NE.

But basically a pretty whooshy Friday with some very nice cluing.¬† I love "coming out party" for BABY SHOWER and "they're green year-round" for FAKE PLANTS.¬† I cop to owning some FAKE PLANTS because I love the look of plants but have always had a black thumb.¬† I'm proving it right now, as someone brought me the cutest, loveliest small plant with gorgeous, abundant deep green leaves and bright pink flowers with a long name I don't remember -- and I'm in the process of killing it, I'm pretty sure -- though I'm watering it religiously, but not, I hope, OVERwatering it,¬† So hard to know.¬† This plant is so, so lovely -- and, alas, so, so doomed.¬† But I've had it since December 30, and it's not dead yet.¬† Can I make it through a full month?¬† We shall see.

An enjoyable puzzle.¬† Some will find it too easy, but I liked the whooshiness.

14 hours left (as of right now) to vote in the first round of THE GRIDDIES, awards for the best NYT puzzles of 2025. Voting ends 11:59 EST tonight. Ballot found here: https://form.jotform.com/253465756808167 Easy to use, nominate as many as five in each of the categories, hit submit and Bob's your uncle! Sample M-W nomination: January 29 (Sophia Maymudes) The revealer was BOTTOMLESS BRUNCH. The grid had 6 entries missing the bottom letter of the bottom word (things that might be consumed at a brunch), such as COUGH SYRU, SAVES ONE‚ÄôS BACO and RAGAMUFFI. Other surprising entries included STREAK BY and KNOCKOFFS. Thursday: October 9 (Freddie Cheng) So many things one can indicate with just the thumbs! The revealer was ALL THUMBS [Klutzy‚Ä¶and a hint to (the four theme answers)]. The first themed clue was [Two down] NO WAY JOSE (Two thumbs down). [One out] I NEED A RIDE (hitchhiking). [Two moving around each other] NOTHING TO DO (twiddling thumbs). [Two up] WORKS FOR ME. Also, the repeated clue [Storage device that has fallen out of fashion] CD ROM & ROLODEX and [The old you?] THOU. Fri-Sat: March 8 (Joe Deeney) An ingenious grid design allowed for 20 10-letter entries, most of which were extremely fresh or debuts, including GOOD OLE BOY and [Common component of ranch dressing?] STETSON HAT, WE‚ÄôRE SO DEAD, APPLE PRESS and HOT AS HADES.

At one point I had to reassure myself that the author Zane Gray was never the king of England. 

I mean, nine days is a brief reign, but you'll still expect someone to notice immediately that something was amiss.

A nice puzzle that challenges you to think outside the box.  ‚ÄòBaby shower‚Äô is a case in point.

Great fun!
Great cluing and novel entries made this a fun romp Friday. Thank you!

One of the hardest I've tried and I'm glad to see that there are not dozens of posts claiming it was too, too easy. Paradoxically, I didn't think of face plant, it's not an expression I'm very familiar with, so FAKE wasn't hard. 

I didn't know quite a few. FLOTUS sounds vaguely unsavoury, like flotsam and detritus.

And I would never put a petrol container in the boot of the car. 

I wondered about the media star ATSY MBOLL. 

I discovered that the BABY SHOWER is a newish trend in the UK, but not widespread, usually linked to an afternoon tea. When I was young, it was considered bad luck to buy a pram or cot, or too many baby clothes, before the baby was born. A sad reminder of the not so distant past. 

Despite the nods to the homeland, I found it quite 'American', as it should be, of course.
2-down caused a lot of trouble because having ‚Äúcaw‚Äù at the bottom ‚ÄúMaria‚Äù immediately jumped into my head because of the song, but that was Natalie Wood.

What a great puzzle! I started it during a sleepless hour at about 1 AM, fell back to sleep, finished this morning, so my time was quite long. Perfect Friday, I did not have one answer that irritated me or did not make perfect sense once I got it. I love puzzles like this one, seems hopeless at first but then slowly comes together. More like this please!

The easy mode of this Crosswords was a delight, although it hit a bit too close to home. As I came back from maternity leave this week, I have been told to 17 Across (and that I put my own interest before the company's because I took a maternity leave...), so I would love a 29 Down to get me out of this madness!

Took a whole lot of crosses and head scratching (and maybe just a smidge of Google's time) but finally got there. This is what I'd classify as a super duper Friday puzzle. Veeeery satisfying. Thanks Kyle!

I thought this was fairly easy for a Friday, and nearly got a PB. But very enjoyable with a lot of unique clueing. My favorite was HERDINGCATS at 6D, which was the corporate buzzword featured in one of my favorite Super Bowl commercials of all time, courtesy of EDS in 2000 (along with the Budweiser frogs and Clydesdales, and the hilarious Wasssuuuuup? series). Apologies if this link has already been shared, as searching the comments is (still!) impossible on iOS. https://youtu.be/m_MaJDK3VNE

This was a rather tough Friday puzzle for me. Initially the upper left and lower right got filled in pretty soon, but the two remaining quadrants resisted mightily. When only the lower left was left to fill, again it resisted mightily two or three more times, but when I finally saw the elusive J of JANE GREY, that catalyzed the fall of the remaining dominoes, allowing the solve to snowball and nail the last few clues like low-hanging fruit.

Never heard of JINK. Not sure if I'd ever seen A.A.V.E. or FOREX before.

A terrific crossword that afforded me a bunch more minutes of solving pleasure than usual.

Very difficult for me. I simply was not on the constructor's wavelength. Felt like there wasn't enough intrinsic fill to get the gears going and I had to turn to Ms. Corbin much earlier than I like. Fair game, and I'm not complaining, but this was HARD.

I struggled with 51 Across even though there used to be a shop called FOREX along my morning commute.  I went in there one day to convert some $$$ to various pre-Euro currencies.  Filled in the EX but took this aging brain a long time to remember FOR.  

Eventually got ATSYMBOL but it made no sense to me until I saw where to split it in the comments.  Eons ago I did easy non-NYT puzzles that indicated how many words.

I looked up Jane Grey (1536-1554) and learned that she was an exceptionally learned woman whose accession to the throne and beheading both resulted from her getting swept up in political events outside her control. Given our contemporary scene I wonder what truths about her situation were known by the general public and what plain folks' attitudes toward her were. As they had no elections to look forward to as a way to impact such high-level goings-on, I'm guessing malevolent players in the political power class saw no need to cultivate a disinformation industry. But maybe there wasn't much of an information industry either.

Anyway, pardon that aside on 25 Across.

I got stuck in the SW corner for quite some time (partly because the Welsh language doesn't use the letter V, looking at you, EVAN)... But puzzles are for being puzzled! And so I was... Thank you for a fun and sturdy  workout, Kyle!

I wish XWSTATS gave the standard deviation of solve times, because I suspect today's would be much larger than average. i found it fairly easy for a Friday but clearly lots of folks did not! XWSTATS says it's harder than usual (despite many commenters here saying it was too easy), with the median solve time 15% slower than average. We need more stats!
I guessed LETS ROCK without any crossers. I love when that happens. Lots of fun cluing and fills. Thoroughly enjoyed this puzzle.

I suppose I'm the only one who, when clued "Like leatherette" four letters, instantly puts in "warm."
Or maybe I'm not. 
If you know, you know.

Started off with 15A/9D answer of anyoneheRe/fRee.    Both perfectly logical.    I had to fill out over half the puzzle before I realized this wouldn't work and the correct answers were anyonehoMe/eMit
This was TOUGH!!!!
So creative, so tricky. Loved it!
Loved this one!

If this one were any chewier I‚Äôd‚Äôve broken my teeth on it. Great Friday diversion!

Fun puzzle but a rare editing miss with APOLLOVII. 

The Apollo missions have never used Roman numerals in the names, and unless it‚Äôs fair game to just swap any Arabic number with a Roman numeral, this is an incorrect answer. This would be akin to using FORMULAI instead of FORMULAONE.
That felt very tough for a non- American, but still interesting. (Lady) JANE GREY one of very few gimmes.

I'm kind of annoyed at myself. When I saw the clue for 1A, I thought, "haha, maybe it's a baby shower." And that seemed like such a silly pun that I didn't even check whether BABYSHOWER had the right number of letters and left this entry blank until I'd basically completed the puzzle and could tell that was the answer from the crossing letters. I must remember that just becauze a pun is silly doesn't mean they won't uze it in a crossword clue.

Thursday nomination sample:

Jan. 30 (Joe Marquez) Puzzle themed around the [Uncertainties of life] UPS AND DOWNS.  4 Across answers intersected a stack of 3 circles heading upwards.  To make sense of the clue, the Across answers had to be read by going up and then back down the stack before proceeding across. For example, [Focus of product development test] Across letters: USEARCH.  Three letter stack beginning at the S: SER. Answer: USER RESEARCH. [Mercenary] Across: SOLDIERTUNE. Three letter stack beginning at R: ROF. Answer: SOLDIER OF FORTUNE.

May 29 (John Kugelman) The revealer [Give height, as a hairdo ... or a hint for entering the answers to the starred clues] TEASE UP explained that T's jumped up a line, thus [*Mensa, for one] CONSTELLATION appeared in the grid as three separate answers, CONS, ELLA and ION, with the T's appearing in the line above. Similarly, [One with a minority opinion about the shape of the world]: FLAT-EARTHER appeared as AFLA,EAR and HER. Each component of the theme entries was itself a legitimate word (or abbreviation). The only Ts in the grid are ones used in the theme answers. With INVALID, SCALENE, CRINGEY, and [Stage props?] HAND.

Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@Andrzej, ha, no worries, and yeah, I throw myself into these type of things, maybe with a little too much rah-rah...

When I was in my early 20s I dated this woman who worked for a company that sold subscriptions to magazines over the phone; this is before robocalls took over. She could cold-call for hours, hawking subscriptions to Home & Garden, Car & Driver, Time, Life, Kung Foo Weekly, Thimble Collectors Society Journal, Country Life, Turkey Hunters Quarterly, Puzzlemucker Monthly and was so good at it they called her The Phone Queen. She was like a genius, even though she wasn't that charming or sunny. She had a kind of scratchy no-nonsense voice and an offbeat sense of humor. Somehow people found her really appealing and bought subscriptions they never knew they needed, like Squab Man, the Journal of the Pigeon Fancier, and Hibernation Annual. I mocked her, slightly jealous of her unique skill and she challenged me to come down to work and try it myself if I was so smart.

 I took her up on the challenge, and got a training session from one of her co-workers. Sat down, strapped my headset on, and began to call, ready to sell Elle, Mademoiselle, New Yorker... you can guess what happened. I was cussed at, hung up on, toyed with, put on hold, and soundly humiliated. I stuck it out for a couple hours and sold Sports Illustrated, to a six year old boy.

My own subscription with her lapsed, and she didn't ask me to renew.

I try to channel her when I make my GRIDDIES posts!

Sunday nomination sample

February 2 "Two-for-One Special" (Derrick Niederman) 13 squares were filled with a two-letter rebus. The trick was that the rebus worked in only one direction; in the other, it acted as a sort of Schr√∂dinger square. Thus HA{ZM}AT SUIT crossed [Wild/bunch] ZANY or MANY and U{S F}LAG crossed [Slumber/party] SIESTA or FIESTA. The 13 squares had all 26 letters.

July 6 "Escape Room" (Zhou Zhang and Kevin Curry) A memorable central black door with a keyhole you had to fill in with EXIT in order to leave, and a complex group of themed clues and entries that provide sequential hints to allowed you to escape. For example: [Is completely oblivious ‚Ä¶ or a hint to finding the fourth key letter in this
puzzle] DOESN‚ÄôT HAVE A CLUE; [‚Äî] TEE, which you can get by the crosses. TEE was the only answer that literally didn‚Äôt have a clue and ‚ÄúT‚Äù was the last letter to fill in to complete EXIT. 1A also hints at the theme: [Philosopher who wrote "The bureaucracy is a circle from which no one can escape‚Äù] MARX. Standout clue: [It often comes out at night] DENTURE. The intricate mechanics that made it all workable filled one with awe.

March 30 "Mark My Words" (Simeon Seigel) 7 theme entries had clues that were visual puns consisting of a word or two at the most, accompanied by oddly placed punctuation: [*Composed*] ‚Äî WRITTEN IN THE STARS (the asterisks standing for stars and "composed" a synonym for "written." [Alumnus¬∞] ‚Äî POSTGRADUATE

@Phishfinder never put gas cans (with gasoline in them) in your trunk.  A spare empty one can be a good thing to have.

@Andrzej

On my way home from work just now I passed the place where the incident had taken place. Ah, that pang of nostalgia!

@Phishfinder
And never put a filled gas can on your fire escape if the building you live in has one. 

There was a horrendous gas shortage in the the mid-'70s, and I had a long commute that required a lot of gas. I lived in a seven-story apartment house that abutted another one just like it. In those days I slept the sleep of the dead, and nothing would ever wake me. One Sunday I woke up at my usual late hour to a commotion in the street. Looked out the window to see the entire street filled with fire engines. Threw on some clothes and raced down to my lobby, to find it had been set up as a Red Cross disaster area. 

My apartment was on the 6th floor; one on the 6th floor in the other building caught fire, and the firefighters went through both buildings ringing bells and pounding on doors to evacuate the residents. I was the only one who never heard a thing. It was a sheer stroke of luck that the wind was blowing in the direction away from my building. I've always wondered what that might have been like, though I probably would not have lived through it.

But I surely was never going to buy a pickup truck just for that. 

(Neither was I going to pay someone else to bring it to me.)

@Darren leaving aside the question of whether it‚Äôs reasonable to expect oblique clues / ‚Äústretchy‚Äù synonyms on a Friday/Saturday puzzle (and I think the answer is yes):

Using ‚Äúdiverts‚Äù as in ‚ÄúAMUSES‚Äù is absolutely, 100% NOT a stretch. 

In the most literal sense, ‚Äúdivert‚Äù means to change the course/bearing/orientation of something; in this case, someone‚Äôs attention (away from serious thought and toward entertainment). 

To ‚Äúamuse,‚Äù in a similarly literal sense, means to stupefy or to cause someone to be lost in thought. Again, the implication here is the person being amused is being distracted from utilitarian trains of thought. 

Both words have been used to denote entertainment since at least the mid-1600s; ‚Äúamuse‚Äù does not have the advantage here.

Note that even ‚Äúentertain,‚Äù in the strict literal sense, simply means to keep/hold together. Yet again, the implication that you‚Äôre holding someone‚Äôs attention in a mirthful or lighthearted spirit is attested since the mid-1600s.
Crosswords are a diversion, an amusement. No sloppy answers or poor clueing today, just good word puzzling.
